title: West Haven rolls out hurricane readiness plan ahead of active storm season
message:
The City of West Haven is preparing for an active hurricane and tropical storm season.
The city’s Emergency Management Director Rick Fontana held a meeting on Wednesday with city department heads to discuss their hurricane preparedness plan.
Despite hurricane season typically beginning from June through November, in West Haven, the hurricanes more often begin from August through September.
This year will be the first year the City of West Haven has the option for mandatory evacuations.
In addition, West Haven is also improving existing infrastructure in some flood-prone areas, including the installation of gates at the underpass on Campbell Avenue.

title: 2 years after Hurricane Ian , FEMA approves $2 million for Okeechobee County
message:
OKEECHOBEE COUNTY, Fla. — Nearly two years after a monster Hurricane Ian left a trail of damage in Okeechobee County, the federal government has approved a $2 million grant to reimburse the county for debris removal.
Ian, which at one point grew to Category 5 strength, hammered Florida in late September of 2022, downing trees, damaging roofs, and knocking out power to Okeechobee County residents.
"Approximately 180,868 cubic yards of vegetative debris and 4,796 cubic yards of hurricane-generated debris were removed from roads and public property," FEMA said.
WPTV Multiple mobile homes in Okeechobee County were damaged by Hurricane Ian's wrath.
Whitehead said the county is responsible to pay for the hurricane expenses as they're happening, and used money from an emergency fund, that will be replenished with the FEMA reimbursement.

title: 4 . 7 - magnitude earthquake jolts Tokyo area : JMA
message:
Tokyo, July 31 : An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.7 on early Wednesday rocked the Tokyo metropolitan area, the country's weather agency said.
The temblor occurred at 01:47 a.m. local time, measuring 3 on the Japanese seismic intensity scale of 7 in areas in Tokyo, Kanagawa and Chiba Prefecture, said the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA).
At a depth of 120 km, the epicentre was located in Tokyo's 23 wards at a latitude of 35.7 degrees north and a longitude of 139.6 degrees east, Xinhua news agency reported.
The tremors were felt strongly in central Tokyo, with no tsunami warnings issued.
There have been no reports of damage or casualties due to the temblor.

title: Heat Waves Are Creating New Challenges for Art Storage and Logistics
message:
Fine art storage companies are hyper-aware of extreme temperatures and high humidity levels—not to mention hurricane conditions—due to strict industry standards, new climate-control systems, and the mounting expenses and logistical challenges from growing demand for client services.
“Frankly, it feels like things aren’t getting better,” said Francis Petit, director of the New York office for art logistics firm Gander & White.
When it comes to Gander & White’s Palm Beach and Miami offices, there are additional logistical challenges for art transportation and storage services, especially during hurricane season.
Gander & White director Gilles de Greling told ARTnews that every storm is different and that he no longer offers guarantees for hurricane protection and preparedness plans.
“We’re not picking up guys on the street to pick up your art,” de Greling said with a laugh.

title: Tropical Storm Carlotta has formed in the eastern Pacific , forecasters say – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
MIAMI (AP) — Tropical Storm Carlotta has formed in the eastern Pacific, but is moving away from Mexico, forecasters said Wednesday.
The National Hurricane Center in Miami says in an advisory that a tropical depression was upgraded to the tropical storm, with maximum sustained winds of 45 mph (75 kph).
The system is centered about 310 miles (500 kilometers) southwest of Manzanilla, Mexico, and is moving northwest at 12 mph (19 kph).
Carlotta is forecast to become a hurricane on Friday.
However, no coastal watches or warnings were in effect with the storm.

title: Storms wreak havoc on Southeast US leaving 1 dead and thousands without power

In Orangeburg, South Carolina, straight-line winds caused damage in the city's downtown district, blowing down metal from roofs and wood from awnings of downtown businesses.

title: Storms wreak havoc on Southeast US leaving 1 dead and thousands without power
message:
A weather system that produced severe thunderstorms late into the night in the Southeast left one man dead in Georgia, caused damage in a South Carolina town and left hundreds of thousands of electricity customers without power for a time.
Power outages in southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia had declined to about 30,000 by Wednesday morning, down from more than 200,000 in Georgia alone.
In Orangeburg, South Carolina, straight-line winds caused damage in the city's downtown district, blowing down metal from roofs and wood from awnings of downtown businesses.
Officials across southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia said roads were blocked Wednesday because of downed trees and power lines.
No one was injured along the path of the storm, which stayed on the ground for 3.4 miles (5.4 kilometers).

title: CenterPoint wants $1 billion - plus Hurricane Beryl recovery costs to be covered by Houston - area customers – Houston Public Media
message:
CenterPoint EnergyIt took a matter of hours, maybe even minutes, for Hurricane Beryl to knock out electricity for more than 2.2 million customers in the Houston region.
CenterPoint CEO Jason Wells acknowledged during a special Texas Senate committee hearing Monday that the utility company plans to pass its recovery costs onto its 2.8 million customers in the Houston area.
State Sen. Carol Alvarado, a Houston Democrat, asked Wells whether CenterPoint would ask for a rate increase to recoup its storm recovery costs.
CenterPoint intends to increase their rates to recoup the cost of recovering from Hurricane Beryl, passing the cost on to the customer.
Texas also needs a better system for allowing utility companies to recoup their infrastructure and storm recovery costs, that do not correlate to increased costs for customers, according to Haverlah.

(AP) — Vermont’s governor said Wednesday that the latest storms to hit the state have undone much of the cleanup and recovery work done since its last major bout of flooding only weeks ago, and he called on residents to “stick together” amid fears that more bad weather was on its way.
“This time, it’s especially bad after workers spent the past three weeks working furiously to recover from the last flooding, ” Gov.

message:
SANTA FE, N.M. (KRQE) – Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham has signed the only legislation to come out of her recent special session.

title: Political Spin : Irresponsible forest management spawns catastrophic fires
message:
A column by Bruce UzelmanJasper, Alberta is the latest community to experience catastrophic wildfire.
Forest management policies, beginning in the early 1900s, prioritized fire suppression to preserve valuable timber and reforestation with the most commercially valuable species, which were coniferous, particularly pine.
The disastrous fire at Jasper demonstrates the impact of past and present forest management.
B.C.’s Forest Practices Board recommends “landscape forest management,” to provide protection against aggressive wildfire.
Rather, without extensive reform, Jasper is the first of many catastrophic wildfires that will befall Canada’s west in 2024 and beyond.

title: BMKG : Magnitude 5 . 0 Earthquake Jolts Maluku , No Tsunami Threat
message:
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Indonesia's Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) reported that a magnitude 5.0 earthquake struck the east coast of Central Maluku on Wednesday, July 31, 2024, at 6:21 a.m. local time.
The source mechanism analysis shows that the quake had a strike-slip mechanism,” said Daryono, the agency’s head of the quake and tsunami center, on Wednesday, July 31.
Tremors were felt in Central and Southwest Maluku, reaching an intensity of III on the Modified Mercalli Intensity (MMI) scale.
No damages or casualties have been reported, and the BMKG has issued no tsunami warning.
The public is advised to remain calm, not be influenced by baseless issues, and avoid cracked or damaged buildings.

Nearly three weeks ago, he watched helplessly as a man drowned after getting caught while driving through floodwaters from Hurricane Beryl.
More rain was forecast for central and northern Vermont on Wednesday, with the possibility of flash flooding.
The fresh flooding yielded similar scenes of catastrophe as the flooding weeks earlier in which two people died, but on a smaller scale.
It came exactly a year after a previous bout of severe flooding hit Vermont and several other states.

title: 4 . 7 - magnitude earthquake jolts Tokyo area : JMA - Xinhua
message:
TOKYO, July 31 (Xinhua) -- An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.7 on early Wednesday rocked the Tokyo metropolitan area, the country's weather agency said.
The temblor occurred at 01:47 a.m. local time, measuring 3 on the Japanese seismic intensity scale of 7 in areas in Tokyo, Kanagawa and Chiba Prefecture, said the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA).
At a depth of 120 km, the epicenter was located in Tokyo's 23 wards at a latitude of 35.7 degrees north and a longitude of 139.6 degrees east.
The tremors were felt strongly in central Tokyo, with no tsunami warnings issued.
There have been no reports of damage or casualties due to the temblor.

title: Heavy rain , flash flooding makes this July one of the wettest on record
message:
Heavy rain on Tuesday, July 30 that led to flash flooding in parts of Henderson County helped make this one of the wettest Julys on record at the Asheville Regional Airport.
As of Wednesday afternoon, this July ranks as the fifth wettest on record with 10.03 inches of rain.
Much of the rain came during the later part of July, with a daily record of 2.38 inches falling on Monday, July 22.
Monday night's rain brought over five inches to Laurel Park and more than two inches to parts of Etowah, Hendersonville and Flat Rock.
There is a low chance of flash flooding tonight, but anywhere that had heavy rain last night has a better chance of flooding if there is more rain tonight.

title: Tropical Storm Carlotta has formed in the eastern Pacific , forecasters say
message:
MIAMI (AP) — Tropical Storm Carlotta has formed in the eastern Pacific, but is moving away from Mexico, forecasters said Wednesday.
The National Hurricane Center in Miami says in an advisory that a tropical depression was upgraded to the tropical storm, with maximum sustained winds of 45 mph (75 kph).
The system is centered about 310 miles (500 kilometers) southwest of Manzanilla, Mexico, and is moving northwest at 12 mph (19 kph).
Carlotta is forecast to become a hurricane on Friday.
However, no coastal watches or warnings were in effect with the storm.

title: Eastern Pacific Basin Roars to Life
message:
31 Jul 2024 11:15 AMThere are multiple areas of potential tropical formation in the Eastern Pacific ranging from a low to high chance of formation in the next 7 days, including two areas of HIGH likelihood of development off the western coast of Mexico.
The area of low pressure with the highest likelihood of formation has been named "Invest 94-E" by the National Hurricane Center and "a tropical depression is very likely to form within the next couple of days.
The system is forecast to move westward to west-northwestward at 10 to 15 mph during the next several days, remaining offshore of the southern coast of Mexico."
Right now, this is NO threat to land, but will likely create large swells from the Baja through central Mexico.
If it manages to reach Tropical Storm Strength, it will be Caroletta.

title: How stormwater can impact our waterways
message:
LEXINGTON, Ky. (WKYT)—In 2006, the EPA and the Commonwealth sued the City of Lexington, saying that the city failed to properly manage stormwater.
After a system overhaul and some hard work, Lexington won a national award for stormwater mitigation and management in 2018.
When we get rain here in Kentucky, we get stormwater, excess water runoff that doesn’t soak into the ground after a storm.
However, during periods of excessive rainfall, new concerns can arise about stormwater mitigation efforts.
Unlike our sanitary sewer system, stormwater runoff is not treated but discharged directly into our creeks and streams, along with the pollutants it grabbed along the way.

title: New Castle County heat advisory issued . Has Delaware had a historically warm July ?
message:

title: State agencies work to restore West Ashley marsh
message:
CHARLESTON, S.C. (WCSC) - The South Carolina Oyster Recycling and Enhancement team at the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources has been working hard to restore a salt marsh behind a home in one West Ashley neighborhood.
The idea of this project came about in 2017 when a man named John Carr whose Ashleyville neighborhood home is directly in front of the marsh called the South Carolina Aquarium with concerns about the marsh turning into a mudflat.
The South Carolina Aquarium is also helping with this project by gathering community members to volunteer.
The Director of Conservation at the South Carolina Aquarium Sara McDonald says that the reason for this was because of drought and flooding.

title: Why plume of Saharan dust now in Texas is welcome
message:
A thick cloud of Saharan dust shrouds Houston in a gray haze.

With atmospheric conditions becoming unbearable for some residents, triggering seasonal allergy-like symptoms, it's tough to see the silver lining in the Saharan dust cloud—but there is one.

message:

title: Extreme heat to linger in southeast Louisiana for several more days
message:
NEW ORLEANS (WVUE) - While we’re no strangers to heat, the repeated lashing of high temperatures and humidity will pose a higher threat throughout the week.
Highs will rise to the mid to upper 90s with heat index values soaring to 105 to 113 degrees.
Those who work outdoors will be highly impacted as heat illness is cumulative through repeated exposure.
Meaning, that your body remembers being overheated yesterday and the day prior... that can send you into a heat illness episode easily after a few days - even if you’re not as hot.
Our higher heat energy will allow for very heavy downpours and gusty winds.

title: Storms wreak havoc on Southeast US leaving 1 dead and thousands without power
message:
A weather system that produced severe thunderstorms late into the night in the Southeast left one man dead in Georgia, caused damage in a South Carolina town and left hundreds of thousands of electricity customers without power for a time.
Power outages in southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia had declined to about 30,000 by Wednesday morning, down from more than 200,000 in Georgia alone.
In Orangeburg, South Carolina, straight-line winds caused damage in the city's downtown district, blowing down metal from roofs and wood from awnings of downtown businesses.
Officials across southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia said roads were blocked Wednesday because of downed trees and power lines.
No one was injured along the path of the storm, which stayed on the ground for 3.4 miles (5.4 kilometers).

title: Fall Forecast Calls for Stubborn Heat , Increased Wildfire Risks , Severe Weather
message:
Summer heat is expected to last well into autumn across much of America, bringing an increased risk of wildfires and severe weather—especially in the Western U.S. and California.
Much of the nation will experience a delayed transition to cooler temperatures this year, following a summer with intense heat, according to AccuWeather, which issued its 2024 U.S. Fall Forecast on Wednesday.
Related: California Wildfire Outlook: ‘A Challenging Season for Firefighters’The Pacific Northwest is the only region that may expect an early arrival of fall-like weather, including some early-season storms.
The forecast also calls for wildfire activity to increase in September.
It calls for 40,000 to 50,000 wildfires this year, below the historical average of 68,707 wildfires annually.

title: Jacksonville New Bridge Street Project continues with key upgrades
message:
Improvements are continuing with the New Bridge Street Project in Jacksonville.
City officials say infrastructure upgrades will continue on storm drain improvements in the month of August that will take place near the children's museum.
In addition, sidewalk demolition and installation of curb and gutter will take place near Boomtown Furniture to the corner of Bayshore next week on August 5.
The New Bridge Project overall involves a number of enhancements such as water systems, sidewalks, street lighting, landscaping, medians, delivery areas, and the removal of overhead power lines.
The primary objective is to enhance the infrastructure, prevent flooding, and create an attractive corridor that promotes local businesses and welcomes residents.

title: Tampa Electric power lines go underground to push back against storms
message:
Floridians know the drill: Hurricane season hits, big storms take down power lines and residents are left without electricity.
Then came a well-attended community meeting with Tampa Electric representatives, maps and information.
Tampa Electric says about half of its power lines are already underground, mostly in areas of new construction and paid for by developers.
Duke Energy Florida removed 26 miles of overhead lines in 2023 and plans to remove 61 more this year.
Tampa Electric spends about $150 million a year on its Storm Protection Plan, which includes undergrounding lines as well as trimming trees and strengthening power poles.

title: Northern Nevada Dream Center sends rescue bags to hurricane victims
message:
About a week ago, the Northern Nevada Dream Center (NNDC) in Carson City shipped around 260 rescue bags to the East Texas Dream Center for distribution to people in need following the devastation of Hurricane Harvey, NNDC Executive Director Susan Sorenson said.
"When we heard from the East Texas Dream Center about the needs in Houston, we knew our Rescue Bags would be a huge help to the folks there."
Rescue bags are made up of travel-sized toiletries and snacks for men, women, boys and girls, Sorenson said.
"Donations were brought in and we had two nights of packing last week to prepare for Texas," Sorenson said.
Monetary donations can be made online here at the NNDC hurricane relief page, where donors can also get more information of the items most needed.
